title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. That needs to change. Yet the textbook by itself won’t do that.Soyou’re a parent, politely ask a teacher or headteacherthey got the textbook . . .  and plan to use it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: If the “deal” Theresa May has agreed with Brussels robs us of the power to exit the EU Customs Union when WE alone decide, it is not Brexit.If it prevents us from freeing ourselves from EU rules or courts, it is not Brexit.If we pay a £billion “orce” bill without actually leaving the EU’s central institutions, it is not Brexit. title: eu army terrible mistake
story: But there’s something rather wonderful about Donald Trump’s ability to speak the truth, with no frills attached.And not care who he p***es off. It’s quite unusual in a politician.But then I suppose Trumpo isn’t your usual politician.The US President was at it again in France.The idiotic French President Macron has dug up that idea about a European army, run by those genius minds at the EU.Those of us not keen on the EU always worried about this ridiculous notion — but we were told by pro-EU politicians that it would never happen. Another lie.Macron said Europe should have its own armed forces to guard against interference from Russia, China and — the USA.What a rude and stupid statement to make in the run up to Armistice Day.When French people would do well to remember that it was us — and the Yanks — that saved their benighted country.Sometimes I wonderit was worth it.Trump was right on the case, with one of his famous tweets.He des­cribed Macron’s comments as insulting.And he added thatit wasn’t for the Americans, the French would be speaking German by now. Quite right.And he’s right, too, that the EU nations do not pull their weight when it comes to funding the real alliance against our real enemies, Nato.They all like to snipe from the sidelines at the USA.And resent the Americans for their power, influence and success.And for bailing them out of the last war.But then they expect the yanks to spend vast amounts of money protecting them all.Germany, one of the richest countries in the world, spends only . per cent of its GDP on forces for Nato. That is as pathetic as it is typical.The French themselves spend only . per cent.We’re second only to the Americans in our spending — but even then I would argue that it’s not enough.Our Armed Forces have been cut to the bone over the past two decades.Would we be able to retake the Falkland Islands now,Argentina invaded  I doubt it.The truth is that Nato is the one alliance of which we should be glad to be a member.It is an alliance of largely civilised, largely democratic countries which has held fast against tyrants, despots and warmongers for  years.Most notably, of course, the Cold War, in which the Soviet Union was defeated without a shot being fired.But now Trump is getting a bit tired of Nato because the US always has to spend, spend, spend.And with the Europeans thinking again of having an EU army there are many who think the days of Nato are numbered.That would be a terrible mistake.An EU army to replace Nato It would be bureau­cratic, incompetent and short-funded.And it would surrender before you could say “Macron”.THE Lord Mayor of Sheffield is a ludicrous dingbat called Magid Magid who has been coughed up from somewhere deep in the bowels of the Green Party.Shortly before Remembrance Day he posted a publicity shot of himself online wearing a white poppy and a T-shirt saying “never again!”A good moment, then, to ask the vital question: Have you ever met someone wearing a white poppy who wasn’t a complete and utter moron We wear red poppies to commemorate the terrible loss of le in battle.People wear white poppies to commemorate themselves and their fatuous sensibilities.It’s called showing off.WAGES have risen at the fastest rate for almost a decade.They went up by nearly three per cent in the three months to September, compared to a year earlier – and about time, too. This has been the real problem with our economy.But it looks like we’re on the right track.UH-OH – the Beast from the East is said to be on its way back.You remember late last winter. Make sure you’re prepared.LUCKY, lucky earthquake victims.Here’s Paris Hilton in Mexico, visiting survivors of the  earthquake.And giving them bottles of Paris Hilton perfume and cushions with “Paris Hilton” stamped across them.Just exactly what they needed.Paris said: “I love the people, I think they are all beautul, they have great hearts, they are beautul inside and out, they are very genuine and incredible.”Just like you, Paris, just like you. A WOMAN who met the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester says she was offered an interesting proposition.Have sex with me, the -year-old goat suggested, and I’ll make you a baroness.Can’t say fairer than that, can you The most I’ve ever offered is a bag of Pickled Onion Monster Munch.Lester has been suspended from the House of Lords as a result.Thing is, it’s always the liberals who get up to this kind of stuff.Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and now Lester.Ladies, I’m telling you,a liberal bloke approaches you in a bar telling you how pro-feminist he is, activate your alarm, call the Old Bill and get the hell out, sharpish.THIS is Sophie Michelle. She makes £k a year by whispering to people over the internet.Usually stuff like: “Hello sweetheart.”She says it stimulates the listener’s “autonomous sensory meridian response”.Which is perhaps the longest phrase for “penis” I have ever heard.MONICA LEWIN­SKY was the young intern who had an affair with President Clinton, back in the s.Come on – you remember. According to reports a cigar was involved.And Monica had a revealing stain on the front of her dress.She’s been talking about the whole episode again.And she says she thought the stuff on her dress was “spinach dip”.Really  If it looked like spinach dip I think Bill should have got himself off to a doctor, pronto.Are you sure it wasn’t cock-a-leekie ASIA BIBI is the Pakistani Christian woman who was sentenced to death for alleged “blasphemy” against the Prophet Muhammad.She then had her sentence commuted and some Pakistani Muslims are going bonkers, as usual.Demanding she have her head cut off. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: lords vote to scrap four year ban for lib dem peer who told woman shed be a baroness if she slept with him
story: Lords voted  to  to send the case back to a standards committee in an extraordinary move.A watchdog earlier this week ordered the  year-old’s suspension for allegedly telling a women’s rights campaigner “sleep with me and I will make you a baroness”.But peers yesterday complained Lord Lester – suspended by the Lib Dems earlier this year - had been treated unfairly.They said his alleged victim Jasvinder Sanghera had not been cross-examined to test the credibility of her claims – which date back to .Furious Labour MP Jess Phillips last night branded the vote a “disgrace” and called for the abolition of the Upper Chamber.She stormed: “I’m apopletic. They’re going on about procedure but this is all about them telling women like me, ‘We’re above the law and we don’t give a stuff what you think.’ It just says ‘We think we’re better than you’.”The backbencher told The Sun: “If ever there was a time to get rid of the House of Lords, this nails it.”Lord Pannick – a close friend of the disgraced peer – said the standards watchdog had “destroyed” his friend’s reputation.He called on peers to block the suspension – claiming Ms Sanghera had sent Lord Lester a book a week after the alleged harassment signed with “love and admiration”.Lord Lester – dubbed Lord Mo-Lester over the incident – faced a ban until .The Privileges and Conduct Committee will now work out what it does next.Lawyers defending Ms Sanghera pointed out Lords had already accepted the Committee’s role – so couldn’t complain when the decision went against them.The Lib Dems suspended Lord Lester when The Sun revealed the stunning allegations in February. The respected QC - the architect of Britain’s race and sex equality laws - was the Lib Dems Lords spokesman for human rights.Lord McFall, the Lords’ senior deputy speaker, said he was “deeply disappointed” by the vote.He said: “I fully support the Commissioner for Standards and the work she has undertaken for many months.“Every step of the way she followed the processes as agreed by the House and that has not been questioned before today.”He added: “I would also like to express my sympathy to the complainant at what must be a very dficult time for her.”

title: real life narco hunter the brit colombia cartel
story: The “British equivalent” of hit drug cartel drama Narcos is revealed in a new book which lts the lid on the perilous action taken to tackle major Colombian and Peruvian drug cartels in the s.In his book “Narco Wars”, author Tom Chandler – not his real name – describes how he arrived in Bogota, Colombia, at the height of the cocaine boom.An HM Customs investigator fluent in Spanish, who had worked as a VAT inspector in Birmingham and was hungry for adventure, he leapt at the chance to become a drugs liaison officer in .The notoriously violent and ruthless drug lord Pablo Escobar was dead, but the Cali Cartel had taken over most of the global supply, and an avalanche of coke was about to hit Europe.The British government wanted Chandler and his team to do the impossible: infiltrate the most powerful crime syndicates on earth and stop their drug shipments.In an interview with The Mirror, Chandler, now in his s, said: “We were the British equivalent of Narcos.”He added that while everyone is aware of the US Drug Enforcement Administration“doing their stuff in Colombia” and boasting of their successes, “we never claimed a single result.“No one even knew the Brits were there, because we didn’t want them to. We weren’t egoists.“Our idea was to let others take the credit and keep our heads down. The DEA were looking for glory. This is the first time the British story has been told.”Chandler, who grew up in Seaham, Co Durham, was sent on a perilous assignment.According to publicity on his book: “The cartel bosses operated like a lethal multi-national organisation, with armies of hitmen and myriad spies in ports, airports, police stations and government offices.“Their intelligence systems flushed out turncoats and traitors, and they ruthlessly exterminated their enemies.“Yet Chandler, an HM Customs investigator fluent in Spanish, knew he could only succeed by recruiting local informants, and went out into the field to find them.”Among those informants was a prostitute who provided details to Chandler while they were together.Within four years he had a network of  agents buried deep inside the trafficking organisations.And the result was “unprecedented”, says the publicity.“Their intel led to the arrest of hundreds of narcos and to the seizure of  tonnes of drugs worth a staggering billion .“Chandlers web disrupted the Bogotá mafia who controlled the main airport and boasted they could put anything on a plane, from drugs to bombs.”The team also penetrated the drug crews who raced coke-laden speedboats to the transit station of Jamaica.And, they dismantled teams who smuggled narcotics through coastal ports and identied the so-called motherships, the largest method of bulk transit ever discovered.But, Chandler and his team “faced appalling risks”.There were “treacherous stool pigeons” working for both sides.Some of his Colombian law-enforcement colleagues were abducted, tortured and killed.Chandler, too, faced a grave threat when the crime lords learned he was responsible for a string of interdictions.He admitted to The Mirror that he felt guilty when a key informant – who was married with kids – was fatally shot by hitmen after a mate betrayed him, saying, “he didn’t deserve to die. To some extent I was to blame.”But Chandler continued securing drug seizures, until he finally burned out and his tour of duty came to an end.Two of his best sources were subsequently murdered, and his bosses dropped the entire overseas informant programme.The National Crime Agency is now responsible for stemming the tide of drugs into the UK.Chandler told The Mirror that although alleged Mexican drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman is on trial in America, he believes the war on drugs has failed.In hindsight, he said, the team’s efforts weren’t worth “a lot of friends” dying as “we are no better off”.Narcos season four, titled Mexico, premieres on Netflix today, with all  episodes available immediately. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family six move thirteen times four months
story: Dean and Amy Coombes were evicted from their house in St Austell, Cornwall, in June, leaving them and their four children - all aged under eight - without a home. The family have since had to live on campsites in a caravan, hotels and pubs all across England.Cornwall Council said it was supporting the family but unfortunately there is a high demand for temporary accommodation, which includes our own housing stock, properties that we rent, or other accommodation.Mr Coombes said they thought three times that their hell was over when they were told a permanent property had been found - only for the offer to be withdrawn time and time again.They say well give you a house and then the next day they say no we wont, Mr Coombes said.It feels like we are being strangled. Your hopes are up and then you are shot down again.We have run out of enthusiasm, added Mrs Coombes.We feel deflated - you want to throw the towel in. You want to give up but know you cant. The kids are the reason we havent given up.The family have had to put their belongings in storage.Mr Coombes said: We left one place in the morning, packed the car with all our bags, drove to St Austell and just waited in the car with the children.Then they rung us up and said we were booked back into the same campsite we had just left.Their child have also had to move schools as a result of the chaos.He said: We dont want much - just a bit of stability and normality for the kids.The kids are asking all of the time - they are confused and have been dragged from pillar to post. We feel guilty they are going through this.I dont want an extravagant house. I just want a place that is suitable for my family, kids and our dog. Im not asking for five acres of land and a swimming pool.Amy added: We feel let down as a family.Its been very stressful for the children - they are struggling to cope with it. Its not fair on them.Were adults - we can cope better than children.Dean said he just wanted stability.A three bedroom house is the minimum, he added. Four bedrooms would be great and five would be bliss.I look every day for private accommodation but they get snapped up. Its very stressful.Neither of us drink though Amy smokes a little.I am grateful for the accommodation weve had but it just feels like weve been failed by the council. Cornwall Council said: Unfortunately accommodation can be dficult to arrange, especially for larger families who have pets.We review the availability of accommodation on a weekly basis and will move families to a more suitable placeappropriate.There is a plan for the family to move in to a privately rented home however like any other move where more than one family is concerned we have to wait for the current tenants to move out before this family can move in.Polly Neate, CEO at housing charity Shelter, said: Hit by budget cuts and a lack of affordable homes, overstretched councils are struggling to keep homeless families within local communities.To put an end to this the government needs to ramp up efforts to build more social housing to give families the chance of a decent and permanent home.

title: arecibo message google doodle
story: Let’s take a look at the historic transmission.Forty-four years ago, a group of scientists at the Arecibo Observatory in the rainforests of Puerto Rico blasted a three-minute radio message into space.This was the first ever attempt to communicate with intelligent le on another planet.The message, consisting of , binary digits, was aimed at the M- cluster of stars using Arecibos powerful megawatt transmitter which has a  metre antenna.Professor Donald Campbell, who was a research associate at the Arecibo Observatory at the time, said: “It was strictly a symbolic event, to show that we could do it.”The message was developed by academics from Cornell University led by Dr Frank Drake – the legendary astronomer known for devising the Drake Equation which estimates the number of planets which could host alien le in our galaxy.Speaking about the Arecibo message Dr Drake said: “What could we do that would be spectacular  We could send a message.”The M- star system is , light years away from our planet meaning the message will arrive at its destination in roughly , years.Google said: In the  years since it was first transmitted, the message has travelled only  trillion miles, only a tiny fraction of the ,,,,, or so miles to its final destination.In , the search engine founders Larry and Sergey drew a stick figure behind the second o of Google as a message to show that they were out of office at the Burning Man festival and with that, Google Doodles were born.The company decided that they should decorate the logo to mark cultural moments and it soon became clear that users really enjoyed the change to the Google homepage.In that same year, a turkey was added to Thanksgiving and two pumpkins appeared as the os for Halloween the following year.Now, there is a full team of doodlers, illustrators, graphic designers, animators and classically trained artists who help create what you see on those days.Among the Doodles published in  were ones commemorating cartographer Abraham Ortelius, Egyptian actor Omar Shar and St Patricks Day.And of course there was a whole series for the football World Cup in Russia.Earlier in the year, the search giant celebrated the Paralympics in   in Pyeongchang with an animated design celebrating each of the sports the winter Paralympians competed in.Before it became the company that has defined the era of the internet, Google evolved out of an academic project started by Larry Page and Sergey Brin.In , the then PhD students at Stanford University were interested in the mathematical properties of the world wide web and made it the focus of their major academic paper.The following year they built an early internet search engine at google.stanford.edu and on September , , they launched the service we now take for granted almost every day.There’s a lot you would know about the company that has come to dominate internet search, digital advertising, tech software and hardware, but also a lot you probably don’t.For example, to maintain Google’s vast lawns at its headquarters in Mountain View, Calornia, the company hires hungry goats.In , the company posted a blog post detailing how it employed a herd of about  goats to mow the grass around its campus.

title: us vice president mike pence stares down vladimir putin as he confronts russian leader over election meddling in secret summit chat
story: Putin said he and Pence spoke on the side-lines of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations conference in Singapore, discussing arms control and other issues.Pence and Putin discussed the upcoming G Summit and touched on the issues that will be discussed when President Trump and President Putin are both in Argentina for the summit, according to the vice presidents press secretary, Alyssa Farah.The G Summit will be held in Buenos Aires at the end of November.An NBC reporter tweeted: “New per the @VP’s Office—gt The VP’s office says Vice President Pence directly addressed Russian meddling in the  election in a conversation with Vladimir Putin on Thursday in Singapore.“The conversation took place following the plenary session this afternoon at ASEAN.”Pence reportedly told NBC he wasnt in a position at the dinner to say more.He said: “Well we really didnt have the opportunity he was literally across a broad table.“Look, weve been very clear about this administrations commitment to ensure, whether it be Russia or other countries, that theres no tolerance for meddling in our elections.”He also mentioned that the US had taken “decisive action” to protect the integrity of the ballot box.He added: “I know the president has also made that very clear in his meetings with the president in the past.”Putin and Pence have planned another meeting due in a few weeks.Putin said Moscow and Washington need to discuss the future of the  New START arms-reduction agreement and the situation around the  Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty.Trump has stated his intention to withdraw from the INF.The INF treaty is a  arms control agreement between the US and the Soviet Union – now the Russian Federation.It eliminated all nuclear and conventional missiles, as well as their launches, with ranges of -,kmshort range, and ,-,km -, miles, intermediate-range.But, the INF treaty didn’t cover sea-launched missiles.Putin said Thursday thathe and Trump meet as expected in Argentina later this month, they will also discuss Syria, North Korea and Iran.Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told Dozhd TV: “The fact that America has become unpredictable lately is no secret to anyone.“Such unpredictability from the largest country, the most powerful economy in the world, is the subject of deep global concern.”

title: ministers in secret talks with labour to create brexit government of national unity like in wwii
story: Emergency planning has already begun for le after Theresa May, as the Prime Minister hangs onto power by her fingertips.Some ministers have initiated secret talks with moderate Labour MPs for a World War Two-style coalition government as the only hope of ending the Brexit deadlock in the Commons.One mid-ranking minister involved in the clandestine talks told The Sun: “We are speaking to sensible Labour people to see what might be possible.“It’s early days, but we may well end up needing to govern with them when Theresa goes. It really is that bad in my view.”Winston Churchill presided over a Conservative-led coalition government from  to  where both Labour and the Tories worked together.Labours John McDonnell backed the idea  of working across the parties, telling Radio : I think we can secure a majority.I think what is emerging within the House of Commons now is almost a unity  to avoid a no-deal.But Theresa May has vowed to fight on, saying she believed in her Brexit deal with every fibre of my being despite the open warfare in her cabinet.Last night Tory Ken Clarke hinted he would support a Government of National Unity.He told Channel  News last night: The Corbynistas are a waste of time, they’re hardline Brexiteers. Jacob Rees-Mogg’s followers are a waste of time, they’re all hardline nationalists.But in between, it’s time for all good men to come and rally to the interests of the country.”The news comes as Mrs May faces a fight to stay in her job today - with a vote of no confidence in her leadership looking ever more likely.This morning angry voters demanded she quit during a live radio interview.And the PM hinted she could change her Brexit plans in a last-ditch plan to get MPs to sign it off.She received a huge boost this morning as it emerged Michael Gove will stay in the Cabinet - even though he turned down the chance to be Brexit Secretary.As Westminster braced for another day of high drama:

title: ivf test parents pick kids intelligence
story: A new test has been created to identy embryos at risk of severely low intelligence, its emerged.It raises the debate around designer babies yet again, and suggests parents could opt not to have less intelligent kids.The firm behind the test, Genomic Prediction, said it has started talks with several IVF clinics to provide it to customers, New Scientist reports.Bosses say the test will only be available where theres a risk of mental disability, but it raises the possibility of the same approach being used more widely in future.The firms co-founder Stephen Hsu, told New Scientist: I think people are going to demand it.If we dont do it, some other company will.The controversial test is currently only being considered in the US.Before it could be offered in the UK the test would have to be given the green light and licensed by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority.The test gives parents risk scores for a range of conditions before their fertilised embryos are implanted back into the womb.It means they can pick embryos based on the risk of conditions like breast cancer and diabetes, which are affected by hundreds of genes.But its come under fire for the ability to screen embryos based on intelligence.While it cant predict an embryos exact IQ, the test can identy those at the extreme ends of the spectrum - giving parents the chance to avoid having a child with a IQ score lower than .Nathan Treff, Genomic Predictions chief scientic officer, said its just an extension of screening that is already used to identy embryos at risk of Downs syndrome.For complex disorders though we have to evaluate the entire genome in order to get the risk, he said.The very extreme end of risk, the opposite of intellectual ability, is intellectual disability.There is a potential to avoid that condition by selecting an embryo that does not have it.Screening embryos has been a part of the IVF process for years.But until now, tests have only been able to identy conditions affected by mutations of single genes.The new test gives scientists the ability to screen for conditions where lots of dferent genetic mutations are responsible.Ewan Birney, director of the European Bioinformatics Institute said he has concerns about the test.He told The Times there could be unintended consequences that scientists cannot yet predict.And he said a rigorous ethical debate would be needed before any such test was used in UK clinics.Meanwhile, Simon Fishel, president of Care Fertility, told The Times he believes the test is necessary.Its always about balancing the good versus the potential for bad, he said.When the first genetic screening was introduced for IVF, he said the same debate raged.Without a shadow of a doubt its been lesaving, he added.Cognitive disability is a health issue. Were not talking about whether we need to make more intelligent people in society.

title: funny coincidences photo gallery
story: And in our digital age, theres enough cameras around to snap a photo at just the right moment to capture a truly hilarious image.Sometimes, its a matter of being in the right place at the right time.But it can also be a question of having the kind of mind that notices strange coincidences and patterns in the world around you.And all over the globe, people delight social media users by sharing their perfectly-timed shots online.Heres a gallery of some of the best weird and wonderful flukes.

title: second brexit referendum more likely than ever as fresh poll shows voters want another say
story: Labours deputy leader said yet another isive referendum campaign was more likely now given the weakness of the Prime Minister, who is clinging to power by her fingertips.He told the House Magazine: She leads a government without a majority, it now looks like she leads a Cabinet without a majority as well.Given the weakness of her own government, I think it is more likely that we could get there.He went on to say the party had had the option on the table for months but at that time, it seemed very unlikely that there would be a people’s vote, that was the insurance option at the end of a series of unlikely events.It comes just days after Jeremy Corbyn told a German paper: We cant stop Brexit - but his colleagues insisted a second vote could still be on the cards.Sir Keir Starmer and Emily Thornberry both argued thatthere was no general election, Labour could fight for another vote.But insiders fear that it would destroy the publics trust in politicians, and Labour would alienate Leave votersthere were a freshto the ballot box.Earlier this week Mrs May gave hope to Remainers as she said that there was a possibility of there being no Brexit at all.Shes repeatedly said she WONT call for another referendum, as it would betray those who voted Leave before.Yesterday she insisted that ministers were NOT planning for another ballot.Today in another high-drama day in Westminster:In the first survey since Mrs Mays deal came out,  per cent said they wanted a fresh referendum - and more said they wanted to Remain than leave.The number of people who want a fresh vote spikes to  per centMrs Mays deal is voted down in the House of Commons.The deal will go to a vote of MPs in the coming weeks, but dozens are expected to rebel and could torpedo it.Three quarters of those polled think the deal doesnt match up to the promises the PM made after the Brexit vote two years ago.

title: what happens if parliament passes theresa mays draft brexit deal
story: Butthe PMs Brexit deal passes , the UK could face more political turmoil by the time  arrives.Locked into the customs union indefinitely through the issue of the Irish backstop, the UK would have to apply the EUs tarf and would be unable to sign free-trade deals on goods with other countries.Some argue the backstop is a ploy to keep the UK in by the backdoor.Mays plan would promise to keep the UK in the EUs powerful regulatory orbit.The European Commission, for example, would retain the power to overturn a UK government decision to subsidise a factory in Northern Ireland.Negotiations would start on  March , the day after Brexit day.They would take place during a -month standstill transition period when the UK would continue to follow all EU law while having no ministers, MEPs or other decision-makers at the table.The problem here is thatthe negotiating time is too short, the transition time wouldnt be worth the effort, whilstit was too long, the worlds sixth largest economy would be trapped in a broken-down marriage with the EU.Eventhe Brexit deal becomes law, it would be only the end of the beginning of the road out of the EU.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum world worst parking firm mexico manchester airpoirt
story: Zoe Parr, , was shocked to find a £ fine from the supermarket - despite entrusting her car with a meet and greet parking company as she set off on her trip.The penalty notice was sent with a CCTV camera snapshot of a stranger driving into Asda in her BMW d M Sport on the second day of her holiday.The company, Manchester Airport Parking Services Ltd., was last month dubbed the worlds worst airport parking meet and greet and has been repeatedly accused of losing cars, as well as damaging a Range Rover in a collision with a bus.Mum-of-two Zoe, from Wolverhampton, said: Its completely unacceptable what they have done.They have been using it as a freebie because the petrol tank was empty when it ed to us.Its was absolutely appalling behaviour from a professional meet and greet car parking firm.For them to have taken the car out for their own personal use whilst we were on holiday is quite cheeky really.Asda has now dropped the fine, but the meet and greet parking company has still refused to apologise or refund her.Zoe and her new husband, who doesnt want to be named, jetted off from Manchester Airport on a two-week honeymoon break on July .They paid for a meet and greet service with Manchester Airport Parking Services Ltd, and Zoe made a note there was , miles on the clock.They chose the firm because the website boasted customers get a park happy experience with every stay, she said.But when she landed back in Manchester a fortnight later, she discovered there was an extra  miles on the clock, leaving the petrol tank virtually empty.When the man came to drop it off it suddenly, he just dropped the keys in my hand and dashed away rapidly, she said.That was when we got into the car and released that something isnt quite right.There were crumbs all over the back seat and the petrol light was on so I knew then that the car had been driven.Zoe said they gobsmacked at then being confronted with the fine from the Asda store in Oldham.She said they also contacted the police, but were told they could not prosecute because they dont know who the driver was at the time of it being in Asda.And she says she is yet to receive an explanation from the company - despite contacting them seven times.I have gone through hell trying to find out what happened to our car, its actually spoiled our honeymoon completely, said Zoe.I feel like I have been burgled because the police cannot do anything in taking action against this firm. The whole experience has been absolutely disgusting.Manchester Airport Car Parking Services has not responded to a request for comment.It comes after the firm was accused of losing cars and racking up speeding tickets over the past few years.One young family with a three-month-old baby claimed they were stranded for hours after the company allegedly crashed their car into a tree in June this year.While another couple claimed the same firm had lost their car and denied ever having it - until cops located it  days later.

title: ramzan kadyrov instagram kittens
story: However, behind this veneer lies an incredibly dangerous warlord with a notoriously fearsome reputation.The -year-old leader caused a stir this week after his Instagram account - which boasted .million followers before being blocked because of US sanctions - was reinstated briefly.He took the opportunity to post a poem about his favourite gun, before he was once again removed from the social media .Posing with baby animals including kittens, chicks and goats, Kadyrov displays his softer side online - a far cry from his fearsome dictator reputation, allegedly responsible for a whole host of kidnappings, assassinations and torture.Kadyrov rose to power in , appointed as leader of the Russian region by president Vladimir Putin to fill the role after his father’s death.Here, Sun Online reveals allegations of the much darker side to the cute cat pics and celebrity pals, looking at the controversial reality of the Chechen president’s le compared to his bizarre online persona.Pals with Putin and leader of the predominantly Muslim region in southern Russia, Kadyrov has aired some controversial views when it comes to the LGBTQ community.Ramzan caused international outrage after a wave of alleged state-sponsored violence against gay or bisexual men.According to reports, over  innocent men were rounded up and sent to detention centres, where they were beaten and tortured.Kadyrov denied LGBT people exist in his country, and said gay people should be sent abroad to pury our blood.When questioned about the alleged round-up, abduction and torture of gay men, Kadyrov replied: This is nonsense.Honour killings began after the authorities outed many men to their families.The president has strong views on women too - urging his fans to lock them up to stop them airing their views on certain topics.His strong comments came following criticism about the controversial marriage of a -year-old police chief to a -year-old girl, with some believing she was being forced into it.Kadyrov supported the match and described it as the wedding of the millennium, then instructed men to deny their wives the use of WhatsApp.He also said: “Lock them in, do not let them go out, and they will not post anything.“The family honour is the most important thing. Do not write such things. Men, do take your women out of WhatsApp.”Under Kadyrovs alleged ruthless regime, minor offences can mean major punishments.Possession of drugs is reportedly admonished with torture, beatings and disappearances.According to the Independent, Kadyrov is quoted as saying of drug users: “Shoot them, to hell with them. Nothing matters – the law, no law. Shoot them, do you understand ”A number of his critics and political opponents have reportedly been murdered over the years - something Kadyrov denies involvement in.In , human rights group Memorial named  detainees among  feared to have been secretly shot dead by police in Chechnya.The group claimed they had questioned Chechen officials for information on the missing men, but they refused to tell us whether they were dead or alive.Despite his fearsome reputation to those who cross him, Ramzan is seemingly generous to those in his favour.He recently gave a , white Mercedes Benz C to a five-year-old, an act which was later publicised on Instagram.In a move that clearly delighted Ramzan, Rahim Kurayev - dubbed the Chechen Schwarzenegger - did , push ups in two hours and  minutes.The youngster posted a series of photos of himself with the president, and his new sports car, to his , followers.The leader has also hosted a whole array of celebs and has some very famous connections, who are seemingly unfazed by his reputation.American boxer Floyd Mayweather stepped off his private jet in Grozny, Chechyna in  to be greeted by Kadyrov, and they recently went rle shooting.The president has also entertained actor Jean Claude Van Damme, reportedly watching a play together before having dinner.Oscar winning actress Hillary Swank attended his birthday in , which she apologised for after public outrage, admitting she hadnt been aware of his human rights record.Hes also spent time with the likes of football legend Ronaldinho, and Liz Hurley, who he met through her co-star Gerard Depardieu in , while filming out there.Despite his tyrant reputation, it seems Ramzan has a soft spot – for baby animals.His Instagram account was littered with images of the hardman posing with an array of animals, from kittens to goats and tiger cubs.In one, he can be seen next to Liz Hurley, who is clutching a tiny white kitten.He has had a menagerie of exotic pets over the years, including a pet tiger and lion.The lion was given to him as a present when his baby son was born in November .He was also reported to keep a bear, wolf and a number of fighting dogs, which are kept in one of his army bases.According to Russian news agencies, Kadyrov has one we, and  children – two of whom are adopted.He has said in the past that he believes men should be able to marry up to four women.He said: Allah gives permission to have four wives.We arent saying: take four wives, so the man takes them to the registrar and makes it official. But according to our religion, she is a legal we.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dave advert public transport north south divide
story: And when it comes to the railways, even HS has no hope of uniting the ided regions - as was recently proved by an advert for TV channel Dave.The poster showed a tongue-in-cheek commuting decision flowchart which posed responses to the question: Should I try and start a conversation on the train An arrow helpfully leads to the only solution on the chart: No.And it managed to cause regional rts when a photo of the funny flowchart was shared on Reddit by user EchoesofDiscord with the caption: Take heed, northerners.Some northerners immediately lampooned the post as completely daft.Aptly named user BitterTyke wrote: Miserable buggers, Ill talk to me sen then.Another northerner said of the image: This is why southerners are the worst.But they were blasted: To be fair, you Northerners dont quite get it.You walk out of the door of your thatched cottage, shout hello to the milkman across the road, wave at Dobbin over the fence of his field, nod at Mrs Miggins as she sweeps the doorstep of her Pie Shop, walk round the corner and get to work at the farm mine steelworks .If I tried to talk to everyone I saw on my way to work Id have to give up by the station and turn round and go home because it would be gone lunchtime.Even people in the Midlands couldnt resist weighing in to the debate.Gazzlol wrote: Im not even northern, Im Midland scum, but Ive found southerners are generally ruder.But Snowzey argued: As a northerner who has spent the last five years living down south, its not southerners that are rude, its Londoners.

title: universal credit un wreaking havoc
story: In a damning new report, Philip Alston, the UN rapporteur on poverty, said the new flagship benefits system was ruining Brits mental health, finances and work prospects.After a probe into poverty in the UK, he said the Government was in denial about the impact of benefit cuts - and said that leaving the EU could make things even worse.Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily on the working poor, single mothers, the disabled and children, he stormed.After taking a -day tour of the UK, the UN rep looked at Brexit, Universal Credit, cuts to local services and employment.But critics said he shouldnt be focusing on Britain - and should be looking at poverty in third world areas instead.The Australian professor went to Ireland in  too.Tory MPs insisted the plans were a waste of time and money because the UK is one of the richest countries in the world.But today he claimed that one FIFTH of Britain live in poverty - and .million are destitute and cannot afford basics.In a y report he concluded: British compassion for those who are suffering has been replaced by a punitive, mean-spirited, and often callous approach...As the country moves toward Brexit, the Government should adopt policies designed to ensure that the brunt of the resulting economic burden is not borne by its most vulnerable citizens.He was particularly damning about the new flagship benefits system, which roles six payments into one.It is fast falling into Universal Discredit, he said, saying the DWP were more interested in economic savings and sending messages about lestyles than genuinely helping people.Recipients are immediately plunged into further debt and inevitably struggle mightily to survive, he said.Many claimants also feel that they are forced to jump through hoops for the sake of it, fill out pointless job applications for positions that do not match their qualications, and take inappropriate low-paid, temporary work just to avoid debilitating sanctions.One Conservative Party MP with whom I spoke criticised DWP for adopting a military-style command and control approach.Hundreds of Brits have said they are struggling under the new system, and say they have been pushed in to debt for the long wait for payment.One in six Brits are still not getting their first benefits payment on time, new figures revealed this week.Mr Alston blasted the draconian sanctions regime for small errors and said the test and learn approach was treating vulnerable people like guinea pigs and wreak havoc in real peoples’ lives.The digital-focus of Universal Credit was a key part of that, he added, which fails highly vulnerable Brits.The hardest hit are women, children, people with disabilities and pensioners, Mr Alston said.But a Government spokesperson said: We completely disagree with this analysis. With this Government’s changes, household incomes have never been higher, income inequality has fallen, the number of children living in workless households is at a record low and there are now one million fewer people living in absolute poverty compared with .Universal Credit is supporting people into work faster, but we are listening to feedback and have made numerous improvements to the system including ensuring . million households will be up to £ better off a year as a result of raising the work allowance.We are absolutely committed to helping people improve their lives while providing the right support for those who need it.

title: brexiteers could pick their next prime minister candidate at random
story: Ex-Brexit minister Steve Baker, who is urging MPs to send letters of no confidence in the Prime Minister to try and topple her from power, said MPs might end up drawing lots - as long as they avoided the mistakes they made last time.He said that the  leadership contest saw Brexiteers fall over our feet after Boris Johnson pulled out before the contest had even begun.Mr Baker told Sky News today: What we would need to do is identy the plausible candidates, we need to stick them in a room and say lets not repeat the mistake of last time, decide amongst yourselves - evenyou have to draw lots - which one of you is our candidate as a Brexiteer.Michael Gove shocked Westminster by saying he would run against the former Leave heavyweight, but he ended up getting knocked out too.Mrs May won the leadership battle without ever having to do anything after Andrea Leadsom pulled out before the pair faced off against the members.Trying to force Mrs May out gives me no pleasure, Mr Baker insisted today - as he called on MPs to hand in their letters of no confidence to the  committee chairman, Graham Brady.Just over  have publicly said they have done so - but he and other Brexiteers have said they think they secretly have the  needed to spark a vote of no confidence.Desperate Theresa May was forced to make unknown junior minister Stephen Barclay Brexit Secretary today - to take over from the recently departed Michael Gove.Amber Rudd has been brought back into Government to take over from Esther McVey at the Department for Work and Pensions.MPs would in the coming days face a crunch vote in whether or not Mrs May should stay in No, and as party leader.All  Tories would then need to cast their vote in a secret ballot in whether they have confidence in her or not.If one comes, it could take place as early as Monday.If she wins, she stays in power as Prime Minister, and rebels cant try and boot her out for another year.Butshe loses, then a Tory leadership campaign is automatically started.She will stay as Prime Minister until a new leader is appointed.But during that time MPs would nominate each other to replace her. title: 536ad worst year to live plague famine
story: Hard professor Michael McCormick said AD is a prime candidate for the unfortunate accolade of the worst year in the whole of recorded history.At the start of that year, the Middle East, Europe and some parts of Asia faced  months of complete darkness caused by a mysterious fog.It caused snowfall in China, continental-scale crop failure, extreme drought, famine and disease throughout most of the northern hemisphere, reported Daily Mail.The harsh year was caused by a cataclysmic Icelandic eruption, according to scientists.Archaeologist and medieval historian Prof McCormick told Science Magazine the world isnt thought to have recovered until AD - more than  years later.He said: “It was the beginning of one of the worst periods to be alive,not the worst year.”Effects on the climate were so severe that the records tell of “a failure of bread from the years –”.Temperatures in the summer of  fell to between .°C and .°C, making it the coldest decade in the past , years.Historians have long known that the middle of the sixth century was a particularly dark period in what used to be called the Dark Ages.But the source of the mysterious clouds has long been a puzzle.However, McCormick and glaciologist Paul Mayewski at the Climate Change Institute of The University of Maine believe they have figured it out.At a workshop at Hard this week, the team reported that a cataclysmic volcanic eruption in Iceland spewed ash across the Northern Hemisphere early in AD.After that, there were two other massive eruptions in  and .The repeated blows, followed by plague, plunged Europe into economic stagnation that lasted until AD.Volcanic activity is believed to have produced millions of tonnes of ash which spread over vast swathes of the world.Spikes in the ice core for lead proved smelting was taking place to create silver and this coincides with the advent of coin minting which helped revive the economy, according to archaeologist Christopher Loveluck of the University of Nottingham.Researchers found that a century later in AD the silver became the coinage of choice.

title: mum bus journey children give up seats oap
story: The woman explained on the British parenting forum Mumsnet how a woman in her sixties started moaning “loudly” because she wasn’t offered the seats by the mum’s two children, aged four and six.The mum-of-three claried that she was already standing with a baby in the pram and didn’t have a seat to offer to the woman.She gave further context to explain she always has her kids sit in a seat after her son had fallen on the same bus and banged his head on the floor while “standing up and holding on” a few months prior.Going by the username “whatsthepointthen”, she said the older woman kept “shaking her head” throughout the journey.It prompted the mum to pose this question: “Should children give up their seats for their elders ”The answers ied depending on the age of the child and how able-bodied the older person is.Other suggestions were to have the kids share a seat or to have them sit on the mother’s lap.One responder said: “It depends on who is more in need there are too many iables to say who should get the seat.“In your case I would have offered my own seat,you had one and were able to ride the bus safety.“I may also tell my children to share a seat.”Another added: “If they are young enoughyou sit them on your last so everyone can sit down.”One suggested that it depends on the health of the older person.They said: “It depends on the older person’s health.“If they clearly struggle to stand under ordinary circumstances then it is hard for them than it is harder for them than it is for your children and they should get the seat.“Butthey are just old with no obvious infirmity then I don’t see why anyone should give up a seat for them.”Another said it depends on safety of the bus route.They said: “If possible I would have had one on my knee, some bus routes are not suitable for small children to stand up on.”Other responses had little sympathy for the mum.One said: “The six year old should be standing. If he fell he obviously wasn’t holding on properly.”Another added: “I’d expect the six year old to stand for an older lady. That is just basic consideration.“Can your six year old ride a scooter  If so, he’s got a sense of balance ”

title: tom hardy buckingham palace cbe prince charles
story: The actor was snapped on the kids toy wearing a hoody, baseball cap and shorts as he sped around near his home yesterday.But he scrubbed up today in a smart navy suit and matching tie as he received a CBE from Charles.He teamed his dapper look with brogues and slicked back hair.The Venom star beamed with pride as he was handed the award for his contribution to cinema - starring in blockbusters such as The Dark Knight Rises, Dunkirk and Inception.Hardy also became an ambassador for The Princes Trust in  and is understood to have become close with Prince Harry - branding him a f***ing legend in a magazine interview.He also attended the Royals wedding to Meghan Markle earlier this year at Windsor Castle.Other stars receiving a gong today included footballer Jermain Defoe, who was handed an OBE for his services to his foundation.It was launched in  after a hurricane in St Lucia - the Caribbean island his grandparents came from.The Bournemouth star dedicated his award to his little friend Bradley Lowery, who died last year at age just six, due to a rare type of cancer.The pair touched the hearts of the nation when they struck up a close bond after football-mad Bradley was a mascot at his beloved Sunderland where Defoe was a striker.Defoe told Sky Sports: “It’s special, it’s just so surreal. Even in the palace I was stood there like, ‘wow is this really happening ’ Amazing, amazing feeling.“I’d love to dedicate this amazing day, this OBE to my little friend Bradley. Because, everyone knows the relationship I had with Bradley.“I got this for the Jermain Defoe Foundation, but I think above all of that I think it’s the relationship I had with Bradley.“You never expect to receive any award, so to receive something like this, of course it still hurts.“I’ve got some great memories of Bradley, but to receive something like this today, it makes me feel good.”Liverpool legend Sir Kenny Dalglish was given a knighthood by Prince Charles in recognition of an outstanding career on and off the pitch.The ace won three European Cups in seven years as a striker and as a manager earned top-flight league championship titles with Liverpool FC and Blackburn Rovers.He has also raised more than £million for charity work with his we Marina.TV historian Lucy Worsley, who is chief curator at Historic Royal Palaces, was awarded an OBE and entrepreneur Jo Malone was given a CBE for services to the British economy and the GREAT Britain campaign.

title: dominic raab could become next pm
story: The former high-flying lawyer and karate black belt - dubbed one of the “big brains” of the Tory party - quit just  days after being brought into prop up the Government.The MP for Esher and Walton, , was a figurehead for Vote Leave during the  referendum. Mrs May didn’t offer him a job in her new government following the referendum but was drafted in as a Justice Minister a year later after her disastrous  General Election.And a year later he finally got the promotion to Cabinet he had long awaited - drafted in to replace David Davis, who he once served as chief of staff in opposition.Mr Raab’s speech to Tory conference was seen as a leadership pitch - revealing his father escaped from the Holocaust in World War II and vowing to fight anti-Semitism in Jeremy Corbyn’s party until his dying breath.His Czech-born Jewish father escaped to Britain in  as a refugee.Mr Raab, who studied law at Oxford and then Cambridge before becoming a solicitor, is married to a Brazilian marketing executive and the pair live in Thames Ditton in Surrey with their two children.In the  leadership contest Mr Raab initially backed Boris Johnson - but immediately jumped to Michael Gove’s campaign after he withdrew.But after becoming the first Cabinet minister to quit over the Brexit orce deal yesterday, he has put himself in prime position to become the leadership contender Brexiteers can rally around.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
