title: australian view brexit trade deal
story: There is controlling migration, there is the repatriation of British sovereignty, there is saving billions of pounds a year in payments to the EU, which are mainly spent on subsidising Europe’s archaic agriculture sector and subsidies to the poorer countries of the EU.That money can indeed be erted to propping up the NHS.All those arguments were deployed with gusto during the referendum campaign.But there’s another way of looking at the Brexit issue altogether — and it’s this.Britain is seen by much of the world as the mother of democracy.The mother of democracy held a referendum in June  on whether Great Britain should remain in or leave the European Union.In some countries, that may not have counted for much.If the powerful didn’t like the result, they would have ordered another referendum and kept the masses voting until “they got it right”.We’ve seen that game played from time to time.But in the mother of democracy you would take that vote as a clear demonstration of the democratic will of the people.And once the people have spoken, the powerful are expected to organise things so Britain can make the most of what the people want.That is the commonsense approach.It is not the role of those in high office to frustrate the will of the people.It is their role to make the very most of the people’s will.So let’s think about what would be best for Britain.First and foremost the British Government and the British Parliament should have the flexibility to make economic arrangements which maximise Britain’s economic opportunities.Certainly, it makes sense to maintain free trade with the EU.That shouldn’t be too dficult because there already is free trade with the EU.Common sense tells you that it is neither in Britain’s nor the EU’s interests to erect barriers to trade across the channel.But what being outside the EU allows Britain to do is also make free or freeing trade agreements with other countries.Britain should be able to make free trade agreementswith the most powerful economies in the world.The EU tried and failed to negotiate a trade agreement with the Obama administration, which was, to say the least, a pity.But that is done. Britain should be able to make its own FTA with America, opening that largest of all national markets to free access for British companies.And a free trade agreement with the US would also allow the UK to import American goods at the best available prices.The same applies to China. If Australia can negotiate a free trade agreement with China which gives  per cent of Australian exports to China tarf and quota-free access, then Britain can do the same.Countries such as Japan and Australia are also keen to make free trade agreements with the UK.More than that, both those countries have said they would be delighted to have the UK in the great Asia-Pacic trade arrangement, known as the Trans-Pacic Partnership.That includes  countries from Canada to Australia to Mexico to Singapore.So when you stop to think about it, there is a wealth of opportunities Britain could seize outside the EU, whereasthe UK were to stay in the EU, the EU would negotiate trade agreements on Britain’s behalf.Those agreements,they could be concluded at all, wouldn’t be designed just for the UK they would have to suit all the other  countries of the EU, and we know their interests are often very dferent from Britain’s.The EU sees Brexit as a threat.It fears a liberated Britain would steal a competitive advantage over the EU and that investment, as well as trade, would flow more to Britain’s shores than the EU’s.That, ultimately, is why the EU wants to keep Britain in the customs union.If it does, then Brexit will be no threat the EU will make trade policy for the UK and it will also write Britain’s regulatory requirements.The danger of Theresa May’s agreement with the EU is that it runs the risk of locking Britain into the EU regulatory arrangements and denying Britain the opportunity to negotiate trade agreements.In other words, the UK would gain almost nothing from leaving the EU.On the contrary, it would lose one important thing — the right to have a say over regulations and trade policy.So that’s what all the fuss is about.It would be better to crash out of the EU than be locked indefinitely in the single market and the customs union.Indeed, it would be better to stay in the EU and participate in decision-making than leave but let the EU decide the destiny of British regulations and trade policy. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: customs union brexit sun says opinion
story: Let us first say, though, that we cannot help but admire the extraordinary resilience and even good humour she showed for hours on end yesterday as her Government, party and plan fell apart.But there is no point in just doubling down and hoping for the best. Britain must retain the power to leave the Customs Union when WE say. Not when Brussels grants us permission — which it has no intention ever of doing.This is fundamental to Brexit, to reclaiming our sovereignty, including the crucial right to make our own trade deals and open up our markets to the wider world. That has always been central to The Sun’s outward-looking vision of Brexit.Yes, this paper wants our Government to control immigration, just like all non-EU nations, but we DO want skilled migrants coming here to boost our economy and better their lives. And, unlike some, we are entirely relaxed about new blue British passports being printed in France.Our Brexit priority is to trade independently beyond the Brussels club. Locked inside its customs union we cannot. And the PM’s “backstop” agreement would give us LESS power to leave this central institution of the EU than ever before. No one can call that taking back control.This is too valuable a prize to barter away. It is vital for our future prosperity and the EU knows it — which is why it was so desperate to prevent it.Michel Barnier now knows this agreement he has extracted from No and wants the EU to sign off faces a heavy defeat here. Mrs May should go back to him, as her ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab suggests, and try again.Fix that sticking point and her deal might just have a prayer.THE Government’s super-soft deal, as it stands, is not a viable or stable future for Britain. Nor is a second referendum that hands Remainers victory.Britain was already staunchly eurosceptic two years ago when we voted Leave despite the onslaught of state-funded pro-Brussels propaganda. The animosity towards Brussels is tenfold now. Even many Remainers are disgusted at the EU’s behaviour — and the capitulation inherent in our deal.How would the nation respondit went ahead  With rage, at the Tories and the EU whose arrogance enforced it.  The beneficiaries would be Ukip, or a party even more extreme, committed to Brexit in full. The deal would not last.Nor would Remain winning a second vote solely through fear of a no-deal.  It would solve nothing and heal nothing. It would cause mayhem and unrest.The anger of million cheated Leavers, and others who recognise a democratic outrage when they see one, would explode.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit latest theresa may stephen barclay brexit secretary
story: The PM asked Stephen Barclay, the Leave-voting Health Minister, to take over from Dominic Raab as a leadership crisis swirled around her.Rebel Tories have claimed a vote of confidence could be imminent as dozens of furious MPs call for her to be toppled.Mrs May revealed this evening that Mr Barclay, , will be the next Brexit Secretary - but he wont be involved in talks with Brussels.The role, previously one of the most powerful in the Cabinet, has been downgraded and will now only involve preparing Britain for our EU exit.The appointment of the North East Cambridgeshire MP sent shockwaves through Westminster due to his previous low profile.Since then he has served as a Government whip, Treasury Minister and most recently Health Minister.Outside of politics he served in the military before working as a lawyer for the Financial Services Authority, and then - amusingly - at Barclays.Over the summer he warned that Britain mustnt lower any regulatory standards after Brexit.Mr Barclay takes over the top job from Dominic Raab, who quit earlier this week over Theresa Mays Brexit deal.He becomes the third Brexit Secretary in just four months, after David Davis threw in the towel in July.Hes married and has two kids.He said this evening he was delighted to get the role and promised to keep up the momentum to finalise the deal and deliver a Brexit that works for the whole UK.He is believed to have landed the job because he is one of the few Brexit-voting ministers left in the Government.Elected to the Commons in , he was a minister in the Treasury for two years before becoming deputy to the Health Secretary in January.Environment Secretary Mr Gove was last night offered the Brexit Secretary job, but refused because he didnt want the responsibility of promoting Mrs Mays deal.Mrs Mays mini-reshuffle came as she prepared to fight a leadership election which could come early next week.This morning Brexiteer MP Steve Baker told the hardline European Research Group that enough Tories have called for a vote of no confidence to trigger a leadership election - then he admitted this afternoon that he doesnt knowthats true and a vote wont come for several days.Meanwhile pro-Brexit members of the Cabinet vowed they will work together to get the proposed withdrawal agreement torn up.As Westminster endured another day of high drama:Ex-Defence Minister Mark Francois today became the latest MP to call for Mrs May to go, sending a damning letter with the title She just doesnt listen.He said colleagues had repeatedly tried to get Mrs May to change tack, but no one really listened to a word we said.Blasting her aides and close MPs who have never accepted the result of the referendum, he said that Remainers were effectively keeping us in the EU altogether.Mr Francois wrote: They have helped to steer the negotiations in such a way that means, quite simply, we will not in fact leave the European Union but effectively remain within it.This is a betrayal of the decision of .million British people and the clear instruction that was given to all Members of Parliament by them in the referendum.He concluded: Now the details of the deal are available we can see how truly awful it is... I can never vote for this.MPs would in the coming days face a crunch vote in whether or not Mrs May should stay in No, and as party leader.All  Tories would then need to cast their vote in a secret ballot in whether they have confidence in her or not.If one comes, it could take place as early as Monday.If she wins, she stays in power as Prime Minister, and rebels cant try and boot her out for another year.Butshe loses, then a Tory leadership campaign is automatically started.She will stay as Prime Minister until a new leader is appointed.But during that time MPs would nominate each other to replace her. After a few rounds of voting, the numbers will be whittled down to two.Those two will go to the Tory members to fight for their votes, in a campaign that can last several weeks.Whoever wins that vote will become the next Tory leader and Prime Minister.This morning Steve Baker, deputy chair of the ERG, texted allies saying: My count is over  with about a dozen probables on top.But hours later he rowed back and admitted hes not sure how many people have genuinely sent in letters.He told the BBCs Politics Live: Im afraid its leaked out of a WhatsApp group that I said earlier today that my count is over  with another dozen probables on top.But as Ive told colleagues since that leak, only Graham knows the accurate number. My number will be inaccurate because people will withdraw letters, people will say they put letters in when they havent.My count will be inaccurate - it is a grave matter but I think were close.The Sun is aware of the names of  MPs who claim to have sent in letters so far.Sir Graham has remained tight-lipped about the total number hes received, and is understood to have left Westminster for the weekend.This morning Mrs May was confronted by voters on a live LBC radio phone-in - with the very first caller telling her to quit and make way for a real Brexiteer.The caller, a Tory councillor from Louth named Daniel, called on Mrs May to do the right thing in the national interest and stand down to allow someone from the Brexit camp to take the lead - but she was adamant her deal was the only one on the table.Another caller, Gary from Acton, also launched a blistering attack on Mrs May - comparing her to pre-WW PM Neville Chamberlain because shes appeased a foreign power.He said she should resign and make way for Jacob Rees-Mogg - who is leading the rebellion against her.The PM vowed to stay in her job, saying: I am bringing back what I think is the best deal for Britain.She insisted she had seen off attempts by Brussels to split up the UK and place a border between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Mrs May said: What the EU wanted was to separate Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK - we said no.They said they wanted a customs border down the Irish sea... in October they said, OK, we have to do it in a dferent way.She added: From the EUs point of view, they want to see the ECJ still having jurisdiction over us - we are very clear that cannot be the case.Weve held out, weve held our ground and theyve given in.But its a negotiation and any negotiation, complex as it is, is actually a negotiation which leads to compromises.And she hinted the current version of the deal could change ahead of an EU summit pencilled in for next weekend, saying: Weve still got some things to sort out with them.Mrs May added that the agreement would be finalised at the meeting on November  and said: I will then bring that deal back to Parliament.EU envoy Michel Barnier revealed that negotiators on both sides will meet twice over the weekend to try and hammer out further details of the draft text.Allies of the PM today mobilised to speak in favour of her deal and talk up its prospects of passing through the Commons.Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a staunch Brexiteer, said: We are elected to do what is in the national interest. I hope that across Parliament we will recognise that a deal is better than no deal.Businesses do require certainty, confidence as they go forward with their planning.Mrs Mays de facto deputy David Lidington demanded rebel MPs withdraw the letters and accused the of damaging Britain.He blasted: Withdraw them, because I dont think youre doing the country any good by attacking the Prime Minister in this way.Ive seen no plausible alternative plan from any of those criticising her or wanting to challenge her position.I believeit does comes to a challenge the Prime Minister will win handsomely and she will deserve to do so.The PM is clinging to No by her fingertips after two Cabinet ministers were among four to quit over her Brexit deal.Dominic Raab and Esther McVey accused Mrs May of selling out voters by signing up to an agreement which could keep Britain closely tied to the EU for good.Mrs May feared that Michael Gove and up to four others could follow them out of the Cabinet, dealing her authority a fatal blow.It now appears that all her senior ministers apart from Mr Raab and Ms McVey will stay for the foreseeable future.But Andrea Leadsom is leading a group of five - including Mr Gove, Mr Fox, Penny Mordaunt and Chris Grayling - who plan to meet regularly and strike a united pro-Brexit front, including a bid to rewrite the proposed deal.The revelation ramps up the pressure on the PM - because it suggests they could still quit rather than sign up to the existing agreement.Irish leader Leo Varadkar today insisted the deal cant be signicantly changed, saying: This is a withdrawal agreement which took the best part of two years to negotiate involving  countries all of whom have their own particular concerns and interests.If you start trying to amend it or unthink it you might find that the whole thing unravels.Mrs May used a defiant press conference last night to face down her critics, insisting she will battle for her future with every fibre of my being.The PM said: From the very beginning I have known what I wanted to deliver for the British people to honour their vote in the referendum.The British people just want to get on with it - they are looking to the Conservative party to deliver.And asked by The Sunshe would fight against the leadership challenge launched by furious MPs, Mrs May replied: Am I going to see this through  Yes.And she compared herself to England cricket legend Geoffrey Boycott, adding: What do we know about Geoffrey Boycott  He stuck at it and got the runs in the end.

title: stephen barclay new brexit secretary mp north east cambridgeshire
story: Heres what we know about the new boy in the post as he becomes the third person to hold the title in two years.Stephen Paul Barclay has been MP for North East Cambridge since May .The -year-old grew up in Lancashire before joining the army and attending Sandhurst before serving as a Second Lieutenant with the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers for five months.After his short military career he read history at Cambridge University before training as a lawyer and going on to a career in The City.He joined the Conservative Party in  after leaving Cambridge and was twice an unsuccessful parliamentary candidate, contesting Manchester Blackley in  and Lancaster  Wyre in .In  he became Organiser of the Carlton Political Dinner which raises funds for the Conservative Party’s target seats.Barclay was selected in January  to replace outgoing North East Cambridgeshire MP, Malcolm Moss and was voted at the  general election with a majority of ,.After getting to parliament Barclay was elected by fellow MPs to become a member of the Public Accounts Committee.Theresa May  appointed the obscure junior minister to be the next Brexit Secretary after Michael Gove turned the job down - fearing it would prove a poisoned chalice.The PM asked Barclay, a Leave-voting Health Minister, to take over from Dominic Raab as a leadership crisis swirled around her.Mrs May revealed that Barclay, , will be the next Brexit Secretary but wont be involved in talks with Brussels.The role, previously one of the most powerful in the Cabinet, has been downgraded and will now only involve preparing Britain for our EU exit.He is believed to have landed the job because he is one of the few Brexit-voting ministers left in the Government.Environment Secretary Mr Gove was last night offered the Brexit Secretary job, but refused because he didnt want the responsibility of promoting Mrs Mays deal.Mrs Mays mini-reshuffle came as she prepared to fight a leadership election which could come early this week.

title: rose farm kent haunted ghost red lady cottage sale
story: Stunning pictures show the spacious living area, modern kitchen and light-filled dining room in this quirky home in Kent.Other striking shots show the exterior of the house with a balcony, cosy bedrooms and the external holiday cottage on the grounds.Rose Farm is located on Rose Farm Road in Pluckley, Kent and is currently listed by Warner Gray for £k.“This wonderful collection of converted former farm buildings provides a charming, unique home in a beautul setting which offers superb versatility and scope depending on the lestyle required,” states the listing.“Currently arranged as a main   property, with one self contained holiday let, converted approximately two years ago, a photography studio complex and further framing studio.It continues: “However the outbuildings could very easily be convertedto extend the holiday let accommodationdesired.“The main house is full of character with many wonderful full height ceilings, an abundance of beautul exposed timber, tile flooring and open plan layout creating a superb sense of spacious living.“Many rooms enjoy large windows, with bi-fold doors opening to an impressive sprawling verandah which extends the living space considerably and is perfect for relaxation and outdoor entertaining.“In addition the beautul Master Bedroom suite also benefits from a wonderful terrace which links seamlessly to the bedroom with further bi-fold doors opening out, enjoying glorious rural views of the gardens and adjoining countryside.”Pluckley has been branded as possibly the most haunted village in England with the infamous Red Lady ghost heavily contributing to that reputation.The Sun reported that the picturesque rural community is thought to be haunted by  ghosts, making it a top destination for paranormal investigators.Harking back to the s, Lady Dering - the Red Lady - supposedly haunts the grounds of St Nicholas church, where she was buried in a lead coffin in the crypt.Lady Dering is known as the Red Lady after the rose that was apparently placed atop her coffin – and she is said to wander the churchyard in search of the grave of herOther ghosts spotted in the village include the spectre of the highwayman who was killed in a sword fight and pinned to a tree at the Pinnock and a phantom coach and horses that haunts Maltmans Hill.The ghost of a gypsy woman is believed to have been seen at Pinnock Bridge as its thought she lost her le after being accidentally burned to death.On Dicky Busss Lane, the hanging body of a schoolmaster has been seen, while the White Lady stalks the inside of St Nicholas church and the library of her family home Surrenden Dering, which was destroyed by fire in .

title: europe has economic woes of own beyond brexit
story: While the Conservative Party was doing its best to tear itself apart on Thursday, Germany was waking up to the news that its economy had contracted during July, August and September, the first time this had happened since the first three months of  and representing the weakest performance since the beginning of .Gross domestic product in Europes biggest and most important economy contracted by .% during the quarter, worse than most economists had been predicting, representing a contraction of .% on an annualised basis. That compares with the .% quarter-on-quarter growth the UK recently reported and the annualised growth of .% reported in the quarter by the United States.At first glance, the contraction appears to confirm the concerns of many investors that Germany is likely to be caught in the crossfire between China and the United States over trade.Dig a bit deeper, though, and the contraction more reflects bottlenecks in Germanys car-making sector, the backbone of the countrys vast exporting machine, as it grappled with new vehicle emissions testing rules.Volkswagen, Germanys biggest carmaker, was estimated to have around a quarter of a million unsold vehicles parked across Europe at one point earlier this summer.Not only did the new rules create disruption, they also appear to have caused some consumers to put off replacing their vehicles, with new car sales in Germany during September down % on the same month in .:: How Tory MPs could force out May as leader Another factor was that, after the exceptionally hot summer weather, water levels have fallen to record lows in the River Rhine, a key shipping and freight route for German industry.Around half of all European shipping enters the river, a major trade artery, at some point and it has had a severe effect on German industry. The countrys largest oil refinery, in Karlsruhe, sits directly on the Rhine and oil barges have struggled to reach cities such as Cologne, Dusseldorf and Koblenz, pushing up the price of heating oil in those cities as shortages appear.

title: french minister says brexit comes at exorbitant price as he calls uk mps liars

title: dont pity theresa may pity
story: NewsopinionDont pity Theresa May, pity the nations youth betrayed by the lying Tories civil warBrexiteers won’t be happy until they’re doing Vera Lynn impressions in their baths singing “there’ll be huge queues over the side roads of Dover”ShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  NOV Newsopinion "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo observe the latest shenanigans on Planet Tory yesterday was to be filled with anger and disbelief but also with deja vu. Watching a besieged woman Prime Minister vow to stay in the game despite having more sharp metal chucked at her than a kne-throwers’ assistant, took us back to the steps of the British Embassy in Paris in November  and Margaret Thatcher pledging to “fight on and fight to win”. Like Thatcher, May was facing a potentially fatal revolt from her own MPs due to the party’s deep split on Europe.And once again, as Oscar Wilde said about the death of Little Nell, you had to have a heart of stone not to laugh. It was pure comedy gold.  There was Raab C. Exit, the man charged with coming up with a Brexit deal, resigning over the deal he came up with, Cruella McVey doing what she has sanctioned thousands of workers for doing by walking out on her job, and Jacob Rees-Mogg, like Postman Pat in a Lord Snooty suit, delivering a no-confidence letter in his leader. We waited for Penny Mordaunt to reprise her exit from TV’s Splash! by belly-flopping out of the Cabinet, and played Where’s Govey as the absent Environment Secretary was being touted as the gallant knight to rescue Downing Street’s damsel in distress. Some felt pity for May, on the grounds she has tried to make the best of the impossible hand she’s been served. But not me. She’d called an opportunistic general election nobody had wanted, convinced it would win her overwhelming backing for whatever Brexit she chose.  But she failed abysmally and instead of resigning honourably she crawled to the DUP, writing them a blank cheque which they were always going to cash but honour only on their terms. She promised us strong and stable leadership in the toughest of times, then ruled with less backbone than a tapeworm, her every move governed by fear of upsetting the Jurassic element of her party who, to borrow David Cameron’s description of their soul-mates in UKIP, are “fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists”. The only pity any of us should be feeling, as we survey the wreckage of this drawn-out Tory civil war, is for the country’s youth. They’ve been let down by an older generation whose obsession with the past and fears about the wider world, have saddled them with a poorer future than they deserve. I don’t even blame the majority of Leave voters who were duped into believing this Utopian fantasy called Brexit.I blame the devious liars, dressed up as heavyweight politicians, who conned them.  Never forget that David Davis promised a “no-downside” Brexit with “the exact same benefits” of EU membership, Michael Gove assured us that when it came to deal-making “the UK holds most of the cards” and Liam Fox boasted that getting a free trade agreement with Brussels would be “one of the easiest in history”. How’s that going  In the midst of yesterday’s shambles, Tory Alan Duncan accused “absurd” Brexiteers of helping make Britain “ungovernable”. He’s right. They won’t be happy until they’re doing Vera Lynn impressions in their baths singing “there’ll be huge queues over the side roads of Dover”. But a better description of May’s rabble came last month from Army officer-turned-Tory MP Johnny Mercer, who described his party as a “sh*t-show”. Looking at them sacricing the future of a country they claim a superior love for,I’d say that never in the field of political conflict has such a sh*t-show been so deserved by such a shower of treacherous sh*ts.Enjoy their well-deserved disintegration.

title: here your brexit traitors its
story: NewsopinionHere are your Brexit traitors - and its not Theresa MayThe real enemies of the people are the ones who arent doing their jobsShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo years ago, the nation split in two on whether to have a massive constitutional upheaval. The wound has not healed. Every time we come together briefly, be it Royal weddings, bad weather, strikes or other reasons to rekindle the Blitz spirit, someone comes along to rip the sutures out. Any medic will tell you that an injury left untended for two years will attract flies and disease. The patient will pick at it, and people will be repelled by the odour. And so the schism in the British soul - and Brexit makes us all wonder what being British means, what it is for, andit will last longer than our letimes - has drawn opaquely-funded think tanks, millionaires of questionable finances, friends of Boris and organisms who would have long ago witheredthey did not have this flesh to feast on. John Redwood, a man we thought destroyed in  by his inability to sing the Welsh national anthem, lurched to le yesterday to claim Britain should ignore all legal obligations and debts owed to foreign states and spend the money on itself, with no thought for what that might mean for the debts we are owed by others. Alongside him were other backbench leforms often scratched at but rarely bothered with - Kate Hoey, Peter Bone, Andrew Bridgen, Dennis Skinner, Philip Davies. These are the ones who can be relied on to denounce pretty much anything.  Its the ones who think about what theyre doing, though, who are the biggest worry. Boris Johnson, who broods and plots and composes manestos that are all about Boris. Michael Gove, who wants the world to know hes spent  hours considering his position as though hes the real power behind any throne. And Jacob Rees-Mogg, who clutches his cufflinks while delivering the verdict of medieval autocracy on abortion, incest, and why the Irish need to be put in their place. They appear to actively seek a chaos which will destroy those poorer and less shouty than they are. These are the men who demanded a cake called Brexit, insisted the ingredients were available and method quite clear, but saw no need to check the cupboards or the cookbook. They tied the Prime Ministers hands, stuck a kne in her face and then demanded she ice it, too.  On the Opposition benches are  MPs supposed to offer an alternative to this Tory cannibalism but instead concentrating on how to get a Labour government. Plan A appears to be do nothing, which has the merit of not being dficult but has not, in the  years since they began it, achieved anything beyond nothing. All of these people are prepared to go on TV, into Prime Ministers Questions, and call press conferences to denounce, demand and decry a -page document many of them have not bothered to properly read. If they had, they would not act so surprised, as it is in essence the same draft agreement presented at Chequers four months ago. This threatens the union of our four nations! they complain. This is not what people voted for!  Well, precisely. The fact Brexit heralds the break-up of the United Kingdom, renews the threat of terrorism in Northern Ireland and that the ballot paper was lacking in detail is sort of the problem.And of course this is not what people voted for - because THIS IS NOT THE DEAL. Its just a proposed agreement with the EU to allow us to talk about a deal for another decade, while pretending weve left the EU quicker than is logically possible. But these people who think carefully about their position, who take to the airwaves and send out their friends talking about vassal states and betrayals and a botched deal know this. They know its not the deal, they know it is temporary, and more importantly they know YOU didnt read the  pages either.And it is not as though, for all their talk of changing the Prime Minister, anyone  wants the job.  The Tories want to depose their leader, but have no one who wants to succeed her. They talk about letters that arent written and threats that are never fulfilled, and theyve been performing the same psychodrama for  years without ever once reaching the third act. Labour want to gain power because they believe theyre the good guys, but actually dont because they have no idea what to do about the Brexit cake someone  promised to bake. Corbyns current plan is to tell the EU, which is ready to negotiate a deal, that he doesnt want to, and go back and re-negotiate the transition instead. Meanwhile, the people are wondering where the cake is. They are told the recipes been botched, that the chefs hopeless, half the kitchen assistants have resigned, and the waiting staff are all militant communists. And theres an Irishman sitting in the corner getting angry. What should the British do, in such a restaurant  Half of us sit quietly and hope some sort of cake will arrive eventually, and that it wont kill us outright. And the other half huff, say they never wanted any bloody cake anyway, and vow never to be seduced by such offers again.  And nothings fixed. Families are arguing, the Tories are dying, Labour is withering, businesses are leaving, the pound is crashing. Theresa May has no power, but no escape route either - she has no choice but to limp on, like Jesus carrying his own cross to Caly, and will no doubt have to nail herself to it before anyone decides to end her misery. With her or without her, there is no Brexit agreement the Tories could agree on. There is no alternative Labour is prepared to offer. There is no way to overturn a democratic referendum, yet without a resolution it is inevitable this festering injury will kill us. Were like a couple whose most boring, habitual bicker has propelled them to the brink of orce, and are now wishing theyd never made such a thing of it. Whatever way we look, there is nothing but consequences. If we are to heal there is only one logical, British alternative. We must put politics, teams, tribes, Leave, Remain, his, hers, yours and mine, completely aside.  We need what we always do in times of crisis, a government of national unity to rule in Britains best interest, which is to never talk about any of this ever again. No-one gets to call anyone  a loser. Everyone can say they won. We just decide wed rather be together, and that were all going to be on our best behaviour from now on because harmony is not something to be reckless with. No-one voted to lose Northern Ireland. No-one voted for more Tory warfare. No-one wanted a useless Opposition, people resigning after not doing their job properly and blaming someone  for it, a female PM being beaten up every day by public schoolboys, or an EU that appeared to be more sane and reasonable than us. I love you. Lets never mention Brexit again.

title: ros wynne jones un envoy
story: NewsopinionInside austerity-hit Jaywick where girls on their period are so poor they Sellotape toilet paper into their underwearJaywick, which regularly tops the list of ‘most deprived’ parts of the UK, is well used to being the poster child for povertyShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsopinionDaily Mirror Reporter Ros Wynne-Jones on Austin Avenue, Jaywick "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s a sunny day in Jaywick and people are walking along the shyseafront and chatting at their front doors. By lunchtime, there’s already a buzz around the tiny Essex village. Unlike generations of politicians, a United Nations investigator, Philip Alston, is making time to visit during a tour of the UK to shyinvestigate the emergence of ‘extreme poverty’. Today, he delivered his report to a disintegrating UK government what he’s made of the harrowing stories he has been hearing across the country. I hope Alston told ministers about Rob, a nurse, who developed a serious health condition and found himself assessed by “people who barely have a health qualication” and was found ‘fit for work’. Have you got a personal story like this about austerity Britain  Email webnews@mirror “In January I applied for ESA,” Rob told the UN man. “It took them seven weeks to tell me they had never received the form. I had to live on handouts. Going to a foodbank, it really does make you feel worthless.” And I hope Alston told them about a young disabled woman called Mollie who described “watching poverty crippling my mother”. And Rebecca who spoke about the “hostile environment” of zero-hours work. And a young woman called Raven who spoke up about “girls with toilet paper Sellotaped into their underwear” during their period. Jaywick, which regularly tops the list of ‘most deprived’ parts of the UK, is well used to being the poster child for poverty. A few days ago, a picture of one of its streets – Austin Avenue – was used on an attack advert by the Republican party in the United States. “They’ve no right,” Doris Telford, , a retired advocate for elderly people says. “They’ve never even been here.” Scott Michael, , nods. “We’re fed up of people saying we’re a shanty town,” he says. “We’re a community.”  A tenant of one of the houses in the picture asks not to be identied. “I didn’t have a choice about moving here,” she says. “The council moved me out of London because of the benefit cap. It’s a good enough place but the houses are falling down.” Built when motoring was in its infancy, Jaywick’s streets are named after cars, and the street plan was designed to look like a car grille. In the s, newly mobile families were able to get to the seaside at weekends, and a shyproperty developer had the idea of selling them land to build chalets on. During the postwar housing crisis people started moving to Jaywick permanently. Now, decades on, many of these originally shytemporary homes are desperately patched up, or in dereliction, but local spirit remains strong. Even the village’s one pub is called the Never Say Die. Today, at the Community Centre, built on what was once the boating lake, most of Jaywick has squeezed in to see Mr Alston, the man from the UN, and to hear searing testimonies organised by Unite Community.  One man, called Steve, tells Alston he and his we had both been made redundant by the job centre. “The debts just kept racking up,” he says. “We were relying on foodbanks. We could just about afford to feed the kids, but we were missing meals. I felt I needed to provide, as a man, and I couldn’t do it. I didn’t realise how bad it had affected me. “In January , I contemplated taking my own le. I thought no one will miss me, I’m useless. I’m just going to end it.” When he tried to get help he was told he could only have telephone counselling. Another speaker, Trisha, tried to take her own le after getting pound, into debt. She’d worked her whole le for the NHS but left with spinal problems. Help from Christians Against Poverty made her realise “I’ve got a lot to live for and a lot to offer”.  But she adds: “Now, my area has gone to Universal Credit and I’m struggling again. All the clothes I’ve got on now are from the British Heart Foundation. I was six weeks with no money coming in, living off baked beans.” She finishes sadly: “It’s a lonely world out there.” Wheelchair-user Erin’s family went from “a comfortable middle-class two-income household” to near destitution after she had a brain haemorrhage. The family have found themselves excluded from the rental market because of insidious ‘no DSS’ rules. “So I am to be made homeless,” Erin says. “I don’t where I am going to be putting our -year-old child to bed. This is the hostility faced by disabled people under austerity. We’ve even lost the very human right of a home.” Alston is clearly moved by what he’s heard, and he reassures people their testimonies “are not going to be for nothing”.  At the end of the meeting, in carefully chosen words, he echoes one of the final speakers. “Mike says that ‘Austerity is a political choice not an economic necessity’. That’s right. Poverty is a choice. You can choose not to make people poor.” Outside, night has fallen, and opposite the Community Centre the boarded-up Mermaid Inn and the derelict Dolphin Diner are a reminder of what Jaywick once was and could be again, given a fair chance. Today, the world will hear from Alston. How bitterly ironic that while he’s been here one of the politicians most responsible for these stories – Esther McVey, the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions – has resigned. Not from shame, but because she now hopes to become Prime Minister.

title: theresa offering false choice brexit
story: NewsopinionTheresa May is offering  choice on Brexit. There is a better way out of this messTheresa Mays deal represents a national humilition. The only to resolve this is to let the people have a vote, writes Pat McFadden MPShareCommentsByPat McFadden:,  NOV NewsopinionLabour MP Pat McFadden said the deal on offer fails his constituents "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe public were promised that Brexit would mean taking back control. Instead, it has turned into a national humiliation. All the promises of greater sovereignty and a swashbuckling UK negotiating new trade deals have turned to dust. And one by one the advocates of those promises have resigned and walked away. With the publication of the withdrawal agreement we can now see more clearly the reality of Brexit. Instead of taking back control it turns out to be the biggest voluntary surrender of sovereignty in living memory.  The UK – the fth biggest economy in the world – is faced with signing up to the rules which govern our economy with no say over them - and paying tens of billions of pounds for the privilege. The only argument the Prime Minister can come up with for the Agreement is that it was the best we could get and the alternative of no deal is worse. The Government has tried to tell parliament and the country that this agreement must be accepted because no deal would be an economic disaster and would mean a hard border in Northern Ireland. No deal certainly would be a disaster but the idea that it has to be this agreement or no deal at all is a  choice. Parliament would have the opportunity to halt a slide into a no deal departure and, indeed, the Prime Minister herself has admitted this when she said outside Downing St that “no Brexit” is now an option too. She knows this deal satisfies neither Remainers nor Leavers. For two years this has been a theoretical argument with ious models being pitted against one another. It’s not theory anymore. Now we have an agreement which shows the reality of Brexit and exposes just how distant it is from the promises of its leading advocates. I have never believed the measure of our country’s power is just about our degree of sovereignty. Instead, I believe Britain’s power is magnied by the alliances we have with other countries. But even on its own terms this agreement fails to meet the promises of sovereignty made by those who championed Brexit. I know that many of my constituents voted for Brexit and I understand their anger at lack of opportunity and the sense that the economy was not working for them. I passionately believe that areas like the one I represent need a better deal, with more educational opportunities, better jobs, higher pay, more housing and a bigger stake in the future of the country. This agreement gives them none of that and I do not believe many of them voted for an outcome like this.

title: tory brexiteer jacob rees mogg
story: NewsBrexit is Jacob Rees-Moggs big moment - heres a reminder of his viewsHes called for Theresa May to face a leadership challenge. His big moment has arrived. So lets not forget his views on gay rights, abortion, food banks and zero-hour contractsShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsJacob Rees-Mogg is a big-time Brexiteer - so what  does he believe  "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg has fired the starting gun on a challenge to Theresa Mays leadership today. Its his big moment - the pinnacle of months of campaigning for a hard Brexit he knew the Prime Minister wouldnt deliver. The famously plummy-voiced Old Etonian chairs the European Research Group, a forum for the Tories extreme Eurosceptic backbenchers. Today he wrote to Graham Brady, the chair of the influential  committee of Tory MPs calling for a vote of no confidence in Mrs Mays leadership - and his group urged others to follow suit. Its likely to start an avalanche of similar letters to Brady, andhe gets  therell be a vote. If Mrs May loses the vote, shes out.  So who is Jacob Rees-Mogg - and more importantly, what are his views on issues that arent all about Brexit  Heres a quick reminder. Who is Jacob Rees-Mogg   Parliamentary history geek Mr Rees-Mogg, who even wears a double-breasted suit in family snaps, is the son of a former Times newspaper editor and amassed a vast fortune through his City firm Somerset Capital Management. He has six eccentrically-named children with his aristocrat we Helena, whose ancestors include Charles I advisor Thomas Wentworth and former Prime Minister Charles Watson-Wentworth. A painting of his horse hangs in the National Gallery. Her family inherited the sumptuous stately home Wentworth Woodhouse, which was given a pound.million repair grant by the Tory government last year despite soaring homelessness. Mr Rees-Moggs quirky mannerisms have given him a cult status among Tory activists with one, Ross Atkinson, getting a tattoo of the word Moggmentum on his chest. The Mirror later revealed Facebook rants in which Mr Atkinson complained sex assaults were a cultural norm for refugees.  He sparked fury last year by claiming the huge rise of food banks is uplting. The free marketeer insisted the state cant do everything adding: I think there is a need for some private charity on top of what the state provides. The MP told LBC radio: I dont think the state can do everything that it tries. It provides a base of welfare that should allow people to make ends meet during the course of the week but on some occasions that will not work. And to have charitable support given by people voluntarily to support their fellow citizens I think is rather uplting and shows what a good compassionate country we are. There are two Trussell Trust food banks alone in the MPs North East Somerset constituency, while he lives in a Grade II-listed manor house with Helena, the children and a nanny.  Committed Catholic Mr Rees-Mogg said last year he is opposed to abortion, even for women who have been raped. The traditionalist backbencher said he was “completely opposed” to abortion, adding: “Le begins at the point of conception.” Askedhis opposition was so absolute it included cases of rape and incest, he told ITV’s Good Morning Britain: “I’m afraid so. Le is sacrosanct. It begins at the point of conception, and I think it is wrong.” Labours Yvette Cooper said the idea that the Conservative Party would consider someone with Mr Rees-Moggs views as a potential leader was an appalling thought. She added: Eveybody’s entitled to their own personal views and their own personal views and their own conscience views about an issue like abortion, but for somebody who the Conservative Party seem to be suggesting could be the next Prime Minister to want to control women’s bodies in this way, even in cases like rape and incest, I personally find quite shocking.  Speaking at a fringe event at Conservative Party Conference, he said: “I loathe this idea that we’ve got to give baubles to young people. I think it is so desperately condescending. Young people are not some alien species that we have to treat dferently from other voters.” Of Labour he added: “Of course they want to give everyone free tuition. because they’re socialists. They like spending other people’s money. That’s what socialists do.”  In a  article he said zero-hour contracts were an excellent way for students to find work in the university holiday. title: tory ministers slammed scathing un
story: NewsTory ministers slammed in scathing UN report for "inflicting misery" on the poorThe United Nations accuses ministers of being "in denial" about their "mean-spirited and callous" welfare reforms - it says Universal Credit is wreaking havocShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe UNs Philip Alston accused ministers of being in denial about the misery inflicted "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory Government has inflicted “great misery” with its “punitive and mean-spirited” welfare reforms, the United Nations have said.A damning report said ministers were “in denial” about how the Universal Credit had pushed people into poverty.“Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily, especially on the working poor, on single mothers struggling against mighty odds, on people with disabilities who are already marginalised, and on millions of children who are locked into a cycle of poverty from which many will have great dficulty escaping,” the UN’s special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, Philip Alston, said. Mr Alston said the Government’s policies and drastic cuts were “entrenching high levels of poverty and inflicting “unnecessary” hardship in one of the richest countries in the world.  He singled out the failures of the Universal Credit as one of the main reasons why people were being pushed into deprivation.  “British compassion for those who are suffering has been replaced by a punitive, mean-spirited, and often callous approach apparently designed to instill discipline where it is least useful, to impose a rigid order on the lives of those least capable of coping with today’s world, and elevating the goal of enforcing blind compliance over a genuine concern to improve the well-being of those at the lowest levels of British society,” he concluded after his -day visit to the UK. Mr Alston said the roll out of the Universal Credit treated “claimants like guinea pigs” and threatened to “wreak havoc in real peoples’ lives.” “I have heard countless stories from people who told me of the severe hardships they have suffered under Universal Credit.  “When asked about these problems, Government ministers were almost entirely dismissive, blaming political opponents for wanting to sabotage their work, or suggesting that the media didn’t really understand the system and that Universal Credit was unfairly blamed for problems rooted in the old legacy system of benefits,” he said. The report draws a bleak picture of austerity Britain.  Mr Alston said during his visit he has spoken to people who “depend on food banks and charities for their next meal, who are sleeping on friends’ couches because they are homeless and don’t have a safe place for their children to sleep, who have sold sex for money or shelter, children who are growing up in poverty unsure of their future.” He continued: “I’ve also met young people who feel gangs are the only way out of destitution, and people with disabilities who are being told they need to go back to work or lose benefits, against their doctor’s orders. The UN report noted that cuts to local government had seen hundreds of libraries closed, community and youth centres shrunk and underfunded, and public spaces and buildings including parks and recreation centres sold off. “I was told time and again about important public services being pared down, the loss of institutions that would have previously protected vulnerable people, social care services that are at a breaking point, and local government and devolved administrations stretched far too thin. “The Government has remained in a state of denial, and ministers insisted to me that all is well and running according to plan.”  When it was announced the UN was investigating poverty in the UK, the Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg said: “Surely the UN has better ways of wasting money ” A Government spokesman said: “We completely disagree with this analysis. With this Government’s changes, household incomes have never been higher, income inequality has fallen, the number of children living in workless households is at a record low and there are now one million fewer people living in absolute poverty compared with . “Universal Credit is supporting people into work faster, but we are listening to feedback and have made numerous improvements to the system including ensuring . million households will be up to pound better off a year as a result of raising the work allowance.“We are absolutely committed to helping people improve their lives while providing the right support for those who need it.”

title: who stephen barclay new brexit
story: NewsWho is Stephen Barclay  New Brexit Secretary youve never heard ofBritain has its third Brexit Secretary after a forced Cabinet reshuffle. This is Steve Barclays biography, profile, voting record - and why you wont know who he isShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsStephen Barclay now has the unenviable job of planning for No Deal Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK has its third Brexit Secretary in a year and youve almost certainly never heard of him.Stephen Barclay was appointed by Theresa May after both previous holders of the job - David Davis and Dominic Raab - quit over her plans for Brexit .He will now have the job of planning for a disastrous No Deal BrexitTheresa Mays plan falls apart by  March . So who is he, and why is he someone almost no one will recognise  Heres a quick guide.  Stephen Barclay - who calls himself Steve - is the -year-old MP for North East Cambridgeshire. The former Axa insurance lawyer and dad-of-two was born in , the son of a union official and civil servant, and grew up with three brothers who all played rugby. He went to pound,-a-year King Edward VII school in Lytham St Annes, Lancashire, and studied history at Cambridge. He spent his gap year in the army - serving with the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.In perhaps the greatest ever case of nominative determinism, he was also a director at Barclays Bankbefore he became an MP. After trying and failing to join Parliament twice, as far back as , he was finally selected for his safe seat and won in . He was promoted to a government whip under David Cameron in  before rattling through junior ministerial jobs - first at the Treasury, then at the Department of Health. This is his first Cabinet job.  The MP was one of a string of government ministers who publicly said they would campaign to leave the EU. He said of David Camerons deal to remain in : “The deal does not deliver the game changer we need to protect against further EU integration.” That means all three Brexit Secretaries have backed Leave - seen as an important trait to hold the role. But hes not exactly a tub-thumping backer - hes only mentioned the word Brexit in Parliament  times.  Theresa May did try to recruit a more high-profile minister to the role, but struggled - because it meant finding someone who would go out to bat for her Brexit plan. Michael Gove reportedly turned down the job after saying hed only take ithe could renegotiate the -page deal, which Brexiteers say locks the UK under Brussels rules. With  Cabinet ministers reportedly slamming the deal in private - two of whom resigned - the Prime Minister was not exactly spoilt for choice for a new Brexit Secretary. The Prime Ministers spokesman said Mr Barclay was The Prime Ministers choice for the job, but declined to say whether any other MPs were approached to fill the role. Theresa Mays Cabinet has signed off a -page draft Brexit deal with Brussels - and it has enraged Tories. Here are some of the reasons why:The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK We need the EUs permission to quit the backstop European courts will still have a big hold on the UKFOR THE FULL GUIDE CLICK HERE Not as much as you might think. When Dominic Raab was hired earlier this year he was denied the job of actually negotiating the deal. Instead that was led by the Prime Minister herself and her chief civil servant on Brexit, Olly Robbins. What will happen is hell be left to pick up the pieces - quite literally. His job will include planning for No Deal.  Just months after the global financial crash, in February , he spoke out against new regulation of the City saying it would deter investment. He said those backing it were trying to deal with events that only happen once in a letime. He voted in favour of gay marriage in  and against a backbench Bill to legalise assisted dying in . He voted in favour of slashing disability benefit Employment and Support Allowance by pound a week in . He voted in favour of UK airstrikes against Islamic State in Syria in . And he backed the bedroom tax despite asking for pound,. in accommodation expenses, we reported in . Theresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. Even getting it past her Cabinet forced Esther McVey and Dominic Raab to resign. Now she faces two more hurdles - an EU summit with  leaders on November , and then the vote in Parliament at some point before Christmas. MPs are grouped in several factions - their warring opinions are explained more fully here. But or more vote against the deal, they will defeat the deal. Against the deal TORY BREXITEERS: There are up to  , led by Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg. They will vote down a deal that keeps Britain trapped in vassalage with Brussels. TORY HARD REMAINERS: Only about a dozen, but many - including Justine Greening and Jo Johnson - will vote against, instead wanting a second referendum. DUP: Theresa Mays Northern Irish allies - who she handed pound.bn - are -strong. They will vote down the dealit allows customs checks between Ulster and Britain. LABOUR LOYALISTS: About  MPs are consistently loyal to Jeremy Corbyn on Brexit. The party has confirmed theyll be told to vote against the deal because it doesnt meet Labours six tests. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. Theyre likely to oppose the deal to avoid enabling a Brexit.OTHERS: The SNP , Lib Dems , Plaid Cymruand Greensare all likely to vote against. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. NERVOUS LABOUR: Some Labour MPs could BACK a deal - fearing otherwise Britain will be plunged into an even worse No Deal. There could be  or more. Caroline Flint is among them. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against.

title: watership down inspired real life
story: NewsWatership Down was inspired by real le death and destruction but among humans not rabbitsThe BBC is screening a new version of the much loved classic Watership Down story this Christmas but the story has roots in anything but goodwill to all menShareByMatt Roper:,  NOV NewsWatership Down s to screen s with a new version this Christmas "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s as fantastical a story as you could make up - a band of travelling, talking rabbits, one of whom has apocalyptic visions, who go on an epic, yet terrying, journey in search of a promised warren. Watership Down changed the way a generation of children saw their fluffy pets, after getting to know, among others, psychic ‘seer’ Fiver, super smart Blackberry and the brutal and merciless General Woundwort. And it left millions with nightmares after witnessing bunny blood and gore from the start, including rabbits buried alive by bulldozers, bleeding in snares and tearing each other’s throats out. The terror was so much that scenes have reportedly been deliberately toned down in the new BBC Netflix adaptation, starring James McAvoy, Gemma Arterton and Sir Ben Kingsley, which is released next month.  For those who still shiver at the mention of Watership Down, it may come as a surprise to know that Richard Adams’ novel, later made into a film and TV series, was actually based on his own real le experiences. Many of the animals, he later revealed, were modelled on officers from the C Platoon in  Company’s Seaborn Echelon, which the writer commanded as a lieutenant in the Second World War. And many of the gruesome stories in Watership Down also came straight from real le, and specically the Battle of Arnhem, fought over nine days in September  and in which nearly , Allied soldiers were killed, including in Adams’ company.  In his autobiography published in  the author revealed for the first time the real-le identities of two of the rabbits. Hazel, the leader of the band of rabbits who leave their home to found a new warren, was inspired by Adams’ commanding officer, Major John Gford, who he described as “brave in the most self-effacing way” and an “excellent organiser” who rarely raised his voice, just like his novel’s leading character. Gford survived the war, as did Hazel in Adams’ adventure. Warrior rabbit Bigwig, meanwhile, was based on Captain Desmond “Paddy” Kavanagh, who Adams said was “afraid of nothing”, a “sensationalist” and “by nature entirely the public’s image of a parachute officer.  Kavanagh was killed in action aged just  while providing covering fire for his platoon in a battle outside Oosterbeek, according to the author. In the novel, Bigwig was seriously wounded in a final battle with the terrying monster rabbit General Woundwort, but survived his injuries to become the warren leader - perhaps Adams’ way of honouring his brave real-le friend. Adams also hinted that Fiver, whose frightening vision of impending doom inspires the group’s perilous adventure, is actually based no himself. He said in  that he “identied more” with Fiver, saying he was “rather timid and not much of a fighter… but able to contribute something in the way of intuitive knowledge”.  Today regarded as a modern day classic, Watership Down actually started le as a spontaneous tale he made up to keep his two daughters happy on a long car ride to Stratford-on-Avon. The family was going to see Judi Dench in a production of Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night. After his eldest demanded a story to pass the time, he remembered: “I just began off the top of my head. “‘Once upon a time there were two rabbits, called eh, let me see, Hazel and Fiver, and I’m going to tell you about some of their adventures’. What followed we really the essence of Watership Down.” The story continued over the next few months during the school run, with Adams forming the narrative in his mind as he lay in bed, ready to tell the girls the next morning.  On his daughter’s request, Adams, then  and a civil servant, eventually put pen to paper  months later. Even back then, the story of Hazel, Fiver and the other bunnies sometimes left his daughters scared and unable to sleep, while his we Elizabeth even tried to get him to take out the scene in which Bigwig gets caught in a snare. But Adams later said he wanted the novel to be frightening, explaining to a fan: “Good stories ought to be exciting andthey are exciting they are inevitably scary in parts”. But the novel almost didn’t make it into print after Adams’ manuscript was rejected by at least seven dferent publishers. It was finally picked up by Rex Collings, a one-man publishing outfit in London. Collins wrote to a friend at the time: “I’ve just taken on a novel about rabbits, one of them with extra-sensory perception. Do you think I’m mad ” Originally entitled Hazel and Fiver, Collings who was the first to suggest the name Watership Down. In , Collings printed as many books as he could afford, a run of , - and they sold out immediately. The book went on to win the Carnegie Medal and theChildren’s Prize, before being adapted into an animated feature film in , and a television series which ran from  to .  Today, the book has been translated into  languages and sold more than  million copies worldwide. And who can forget Bright Eyes, Simon and Garfunkel’s folky theme song, which stayed at No in the UK for six weeks in , selling over a million copies  The song, however, has not proved to be so enduring, and will be replaced by a new song performed by Sam Smith for the new remake. Perhaps less well known is that the book also spurned a Dungeons and Dragons-type role-playing game. In Bunnies  Burrows, participants pretended to be “intelligent rabbits” trying to survive food shortages and outsmart humans. The success of Watership Down allowed Adams to live comfortably on the royalties, first as a tax exile at Lhergy-Dhoo on the Isle of Man, then in Whitchurch, Hampshire, until his death in  aged .

Ron English bought Slave Labour, which depicts a child kneeling at a sewing machine producing a string of Union Jack bunting, for , . But, rather than display it proudly, the American artist plans to paint over the mural in protest - because street art “shouldn’t be bought and sold”. The painting appeared on the side of a Poundland shop wall in Wood Green in . It is believed to be a protest against sweatshops used to manufacture souvenirs for the London Olympics. Slave Labour was auctioned in Los Angeles on Wednesday and artist Ron said: “Well my idea for this painting is to whitewash it for my good pal Banksy, I only wish I couldve spent more money for it.New Banksy video suggests Girl With Balloon shredding stunt went WRONGIm going to paint it white again, Im done. “This is a blow for street art. It shouldnt be bought and sold. Im going to paint over it and just include it in one of the walls in my house. “Were tired of people stealing our stuff off the streets and re-selling it so Im just going to buy everything I can get my hands on and whitewash it. Mr English, who said he had spent time in Palestine with Banksy, added: Then of course Ill sell the the whitewash painting for a million dollars. Im crazy but Im not stupid. Banksy slams Russian art gallery for showing his work without permissionThe painting sold for , plus the buyers premium, bringing the total to ,, Darren Julien, of Juliens Auctions said. In , Slave Labour was removed from the north London wall and put up for sale in the US. After an appeal it was ed to the UK and sold at auction in Covent Garden. Meanwhile in October, a Banksy piece sold in London partially shredded itself after the hammer came down. Suspected new Banksy artwork appears in Birmingham streetGirl With Balloon, one of the mysterious artists most famous works, sold for pound. million before the canvas passed through a shredder installed in the frame. The buyer later confirmed they were going through with the sale.

title: cage bed tragic toddler ellie
story: NewsCage bed where tragic toddler Ellie-May was tied up and left to dieEllie-May Minshull Coyles leless body was found in her bed, which had been made into a cage, at Lauren Coyle and Reece Hitchcotts flat in PrestonShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEllie-May Minshull Coyle,  months, died after being tied face-down in a Frozen themed cage bed"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPictures have been released of the horric Frozen-themed cage bed where a toddler was tied face down and eventually died.Lauren Coyle and Reece Hitchcott, both , were found guilty of causing or allowing the death of -month-old Ellie-May Minshull Coyle following a trial, but cleared of her manslaughter. They were each sentenced to  years in prison at Liverpool Crown Court today. Photographs of the bed show slats and sides from her cot had been attached to it with towels and sheets draped over them so the child could not see or get out. The little girl had been forcibly tied to the bed on more than one occasion and restraint marks on her body showed she had had at least one wrist and one ankle tied.  A post-mortem examination found her death was caused by forcible restraint by ligatures in a face down position complicated by hyperthermia. The prosecution said the duvet placed over the tot would have impacted on her ability to control her body temperature, causing her immense suffering, distress and upset. At some point on March , , the little girl stopped breathing and her heart stopped. Coyles father, Sean Coyle, called round to the flat in Preston at sometime between  and .am that morning to check on his daughter and grand-daughter and she told him to be quiet as Ellie-May was sleeping. When he went into her bedroom Hitchcott was crouched over her bed in a gap between the end of the bed and the wall.  He believed he was trying to wake Ellie-May, who was lying on her back.He askedshe was okay and he replied: “Yeah I think so.” Mr Coyle realised something was not right and when he askedshe was breathing. “When Mr Coyle looked at Ellie-May her eyes rolled back into her head and she looked ‘clammy’, the prosecution said during the trial.  Mr Coyle now knew that something terrible had happened to Ellie. An ambulance was called and after ing to the bedroom, Mr Coyle told Hitchcott to get Ellie-May, who still had the duvet over her, out of bed. Hitchcott pulled the covers about half way down the bed and put his hands under her torso and pulled and lted her up. The prosecution queried whether he was struggling to do so as her feet and legs were tied by the pink blanket and other material and he had not had time to unbind her. Mr Coyle and paramedics tried to resuscitate Ellie-May.  She was taken to the Royal Preston Hospital and was declared dead at .am. Police attending the scene found a pink and a blue blanket had been used as ligatures going under the mattress. The blue one - which would have corresponded with Ellie-May’s chest area - was undone but the pink one - which would have corresponded with her legs - was knotted and tied so tightly the sides of the mattress were raised off the bed frame by cm. Coyle later told police Hitchcott had been binding her daughter across the chest with the blue blanket since mid-January saying it would help her settle into a sleep routine and stop her banging her head on the wall.  In a statement which was read to the court, Ellie-Mays father John Minshull said: Every day me and my mum think about Ellie and really miss her, we just wish we could give her a big hug and it breaks our hearts deeply. He added: Now I cant be a dad to her no more, it destroys me inside. The couple, who both denied they had tied the youngster to the bed, were also convicted of one count of child cruelty by caging the child in her bed, and another count of child cruelty by restraining her in the bed. Their lodger, Connor Kirby, , of Octavia Court, Huyton, Liverpool, was cleared of all of the charges.

title: dad spent 10 000 accidentally
story: NewsDad who spent £, accidentally transferred into his bank account thought it was ChristmasBailey Waltons account received an unexpected bonus when his girlfriends boss accidentally added an extra  on to her wages, a court heardShareCommentsByHayley Sewell:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsBailey Walton spent £, wrongly sent by his girlfriend Lauren Woods boss in a bungled bank transfer "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father of two gave away pound, after he was mistakenly sent the money by his girlfriends boss in a bungled bank transaction. Security guard Bailey Walton, , had been struggling to pay back money he blew on betting machines until he discovered the windfall. The father of two thought it was Christmas and over the next month used the forbidden cash to pay off his debts before Lauren Woods boss Joanne Harvey realised the error. It is thought Miss Harvey, who runs a care services firm accidentally put an extra nought on the amount when paying wage money to Miss Wood by BACS. Miss Wood, , knew nothing of the windfall. At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, Walton, of Little Hulton near Salford admitted theft and was ordered to pay back all the cash.  He was also sentenced to  months jail suspended for two years and and complete  unpaid work hours. Miss Wood was initially charged with theft alongside Walton but the case against her was dropped. The court heard the botched transaction occurred on July  whilst Miss Wood was employed by Miss Harvey. Walton had control of the account as Miss Wood was unable to open one and when he saw the money had been deposited he made no contact with Miss Harvey and instead secretly spent the lot. The error was discovered the following month.  Judge Bernard Lever said: The employer made a mistake and he took advantage of this. He got a bank payment and thinks it’s Christmas. He didn’t intend to steal from her - it was her error that caused the problem. The judge told Walton: Your partner was working for a small firm and therefore vulnerable to financial loss. Miss Harvey said her and the company have been caused great problems and inconvenience due to your dishonesty. Your partner didn’t have the stable conduct to have her own account so it was paid into yours. She accidentally made a bank error and gave you  times as much as you should have got, being pound,. Miss Harvey has said the actions caused by the loss to the company has caused upset as a result of your dishonesty. You were not in a position of trust but in responsibility. You have a gambling problem and money issues and you took advantage of the mistake that was made. You could have ed the money, but you dissipated it. Now you will have to pay the money back.  The court heard Walton and Miss Wood have two children, one aged six and the other a baby in need of an operation. Miss Wood currently suffers with post natal depression. Defence lawyer Adam Brown said in mitigation: They have another baby on the way and an eight week old baby currently. They are now living together whilst he works in security at night. Their son has health issues in his stomach and is due to go through chemo surgery and they are combating this together. She is battling with depression. title: mum claims airport parking firm
story: NewsMum claims airport parking firm drove her car  MILES while on holidayZoe Parr, , was sent a £ fine after her car was allegedly parked outside an Asda in ManchesterShareCommentsByRichard PercivalNeil Murphy:,  NOV NewsZoe Parr has expressed her anger over the incident "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum discovered her car had been driven  MILES while she was on holiday after she was sent a fine - with a photo of someone  at the wheel. Mum-of-two Zoe, from Wolverhampton, said: I think that its completely unacceptable. They have been using it as a freebie because the petrol tank was empty when it ed to us. For them to have taken the car out for their own personal use whilst we were on holiday is quite cheeky really. Zoe and her new husband jetted off from Manchester Airport on a two-week honeymoon break to Montego Bay in Jamaica, on July . They chose the firm because the website boasted customers get a park happy experience with every stay, she said. But when she landed back in Manchester a fortnight later, she says there was an extra  miles on the clock, leaving the petrol tank virtually empty.  When the man came to drop it off it suddenly, he just dropped the keys in my hand and dashed away rapidly, she said. That was when we got into the car and released that something isnt quite right. There were crumbs all over the back seat and the petrol light was on so I knew then that the car had been driven. But when the couple got home they had a fine for overstaying at an Asda store in Oldham. The pound fine from Parking Eye said the vehicle arrived at .am before leaving one hour and twenty minutes at .am - and included a photo of the car being driven. Zoe said: We were simply gobsmacked. We immediately called Asda and explained the situation and they agreed to drop the charge. We called Manchester Airport Parking Services Limited and demanded answers.  We complained that the company had been driving our vehicle but they just simply ignored us and said someone will get back to you. This is clearly not the professional service you expect from an airport car service. In August, pound appeared in her bank account from the company - which Zoe assumes was to cover the fine. This was extremely odd, Zoe said. We then phoned Greater Manchester Police to report what had happened with the car.  However after a few weeks of investigation, we were told that we could not prosecute because they dont know who the driver was at the time of it being in Asda. Zoe claims she has contacted the company seven times but said she has not had an explanation. Zoe said: Every time I rang the company, I was just told that someone would get back to me but I never heard anything back. I have gone through hell trying to find out what happened to our car, its actually spoiled our honeymoon completely. I feel like I have been burgled because the police cannot do anything in taking action against this firm. The whole experience has been absolutely disgusting. Manchester Airport Car Parking Services has not responded to a request for comment.
